meanings.sent1: The old fogie always wore a suit and tie.
meanings.sent2: My grandpa is a fogie who prefers writing letters over emails.
meanings.sent3: The fogie at the party insisted on dancing the waltz.
meanings.sent4: She felt like a fogie in a world of ever-changing technology.
meanings.sent5: The fogie's antique car collection was a sight to behold.

meanings.definition: To become old-fashioned or out of touch.
meanings.sent1: Technology advances quickly, causing things to fogie.
meanings.sent2: I fear that my favorite music will fogie over time.
meanings.sent3: His fashion sense began to fogie as he stuck to his old clothes.
meanings.sent4: The once popular trend started to fogie as new styles emerged.
meanings.sent5: The traditional recipes slowly fogie as people opt for fast food.

meanings.definition: A person who is outdated or behind the times.
meanings.sent1: The young students considered their teacher a fogie for using chalkboards.
meanings.sent2: In the fast-paced tech world, he was seen as a fogie for still using a flip phone.
meanings.sent3: The fogie in the office insisted on using a typewriter for all documents.
meanings.sent4: She felt like a fogie among her peers who were all into the latest trends.
meanings.sent5: The company's refusal to adapt made them the fogie in the industry.
